awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Collaborative Research: Reconstructing the data-driven workplace
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will develop evaluation heuristics and methodological innovations to better incorporate worker perspectives into the research and design of data-driven workplace systems.  Advances in sensing technology and data collection are moving us toward a data-driven workplace. Employers can now gather detailed, granular information about workers from digital communication and wearable sensors, leading to benefits such as improved workplace safety and performance improvements. Yet, these same technologies also have potential for negative impacts on workers: to be invasive, hinder worker self-management, and exacerbate poor working environments.  Research into designing workplace analytics to work better for workers faces two key challenges: (1) given complex organizational dynamics, it is hard to immediately predict the long-term outcomes of design decisions on workers; and (2) researchers lack access to information about and data from proprietary systems currently being deployed in the workplace. This project addresses these challenges by collecting and analyzing available archival data from the development of earlier forms of work measurement that form the precedent for systems used today. This data will be used to understand the long-term impact of data advocacy, and to develop heuristics and methods that will provide guidance for contemporary technology practitioners in design of and advocacy for the data-driven workplace. This research will also inform curriculum design for courses on HCI methods and designing technology for social impact, and a summer school for underrepresented scholars on the same topic.

This research answers three questions: (1) How has workplace data been used to advocate for US workers in the past, in an industry facing analogous challenges to data-driven workplaces today? What was effective and ineffective? (2) How do the decisions and challenges of using data to represent worker perspectives map onto analogous methodological challenges that impact the design of workplace measurement analytics today? (3) How can these design techniques and insights from the past be used in present-day workplace analytics and advocacy for workers in data-driven workplaces?  This project answers these questions by combining historical and design research, organized around a case study of management-engineering projects conducted by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union (ILGWU). Archival data will be gathered and analyzed to identify strategies to use data to advocate for workers and to evaluate the long-term impact of those strategies on work in an industry threatened by a volatile economic climate, outsourcing, and automation.  Through an analysis of historical data-driven design methods for the workplace and an interview study with contemporary union organizers on the use of data systems in contemporary organized labor, the project will identify how and in what ways past union strategies, opportunities, and challenges are relevant to contemporary issues in HCI research in data-driven workplaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed design methods and evaluation heuristics for incorporating worker perspectives into the design of workplace data analytics systems. It can be difficult to understand how workplace analytics systems are designed because researchers lack access proprietary systems being used to collect and analyze worker data; and it is difficult to predict their long-term impact because these impacts unfold over longer time frames than are available for contemporary systems. Our project addressed these challenges by collecting and analyzing available historical archival data from the development of earlier forms of work measurement that form the precedent for systems used today. It used this work to demonstrate the value of historical analysis for the contemporary design of digital systems.

The project identified three design strategies for using worker data to advocate for worker interests in a comparative historical case study of earlier data collection in the International Ladies Garment Workers' Union (ILGWU). The first strategy, data transparency, refers to how workers and worker advocates could secure access to data being collected in the workplace, either through cooperation with management or by independent data gathering. The second strategy, wage contestation, describes how workers can use workplace data to evaluate the accuracy and equity of workplace compensation algorithms. The last strategy, selective participation, acknowledges the risks of using data-driven methods for worker advocacy. This historical analysis showed that while there is benefit in reinforcing advocacy arguments with empirical evidence or providing concrete alternatives to management practice, there is also risk that too much participation in management decision-making can undermine a labor organization’s ability to advocate for its members.

The project produced a survey of workplace design methods in Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) and Computer-Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW), which was used to demonstrate how specific methodological tendencies from 1940's industrial scientific management that were active in the ILGWU case have influenced the historical and contemporary development of CSCW methods. It used this analysis to describe how the 3 strategies identified in our historical case can be adapted to contemporary CSCW methods for digital worker advocacy.

The project also conducted research into how data systems were currently being used as part of worker advocacy campaigns. It analyzed the data practices of labor organizers, and found that the collection of more data can lead to less accurate assessments because robust data collection techniques can, in some cases, remove vital mechanisms for organizers to share contextual information about how to make sense of the data being gathered.

Taken together, these historical and contemporary results led to the identification of three key trade-offs in contemporary advocacy around platform labor: (1) trade-offs around the benefit of collecting data in order to base advocacy on quantitative evidence, versus the costs of creating privacy risks for workers and of placing the labor of data collection on worker activists rather than the employer; (2) trade-offs around the benefit of using data experts as part of worker advocacy to be able to analyze and argue against employer strategies, versus the costs of their expertise potentially working against workers' experiences and priorities; (3) trade-offs around the benefits of proposing constructive alternatives to employers for how work could be organized, versus being seen by workers (perhaps correctly) as colluding with employers in ways that might harm employees.

In later stages, this project built on lessons of how to leverage historical analysis in design to generalize these methods to other contexts: technology-infused development projects in postcolonial spaces, and the development of rural digital infrastructure for agriculture and fishing.

At IUPUI, this project resulted in three research publications in ACM conference proceedings and one workshop. Overall, work on this project resulted in eight research publications in ACM conference proceedings (two of which received best paper honorable mentions) and three research workshops.
